Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 09:43PM caligrlof68 wrote: Nurlaw, I was like you... I didn't really want rads if it wasn't necessary as there are some bad SEs and it does affect they type of recon one can get post rad. I pushed until I had my case heard by the tumor board at the local cancer center. Everyone present felt that rads would definitely increase my lifespan and chances for preventing reoccurance. So, I go on the 23rd of this month for my simulation. I am NOT real happy about this, but I am willing to do it if it will give me many more years of healthy lifespan.  I did specifically ask my med onc about SEs...and how many patients he has seen with 2ndary cancers from rads. He said he has only seen 1 pt develop this type of 2ndary cancer from rads. i guess it's not all that common, but the thought of getting cancer from treating cancer seems a little stupid to me. I've already increased my risk of getting leukemia because I had 4 rounds of Adriamycin....GAWD!!! enough already!!! I will be interested in following this thread to see how many gals chime in on the subject.

I have started walking around my neighborhood for exercise...I haven't been released from my surgeon yet, so I cannot resume working out at the gym...but I'm itching to get going with that. Posts.Title: Decision Criteria for Radiation;Risks;Reconstruction Issues nurlaw LynnVA

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 10:02AM caligrlof68 wrote: I, too, have ILC. Has anyone in this thread been tested for the gene that causes diffuse gastric cancer? My surg onc mentioned that the lobular cancers have been tied to this gene (CDH 1). The preventative surgery if you test positive for the gene is gastrectomy (removal of the stomach). Fortunately I tested negative for this genetic disease. Generally there is a strong family history of abdominal cancers that lead you to get tested. Just my 2 cents.. hope it helps someone.
Posts.Title: Mets to abdominal cavity,kidney,urethra nurse-ann waterlily

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 02:45PM caligrlof68 wrote: you should read about the diffuse gastric cancer....it is very interesting stuff.. a lot of tiny tumors spread throughout the abdomen.  I have heard that people were unaware that the cancers were there until the gastrectomy surgery....then they found a bunch of it during pathology!!  I say.. GET TESTED if you have any family history of abd cancers. I am totally disappointed that mammos don't pick up the lobular ca. I also think that our self breast exam education doesn't really teach how to find the lobular ca. I was always taught to feel for a "lump"....not a thicker feeling area. I have since told all my friends what my cancer felt like and they were all shocked to hear it wasn't a lump. I say... tell everyone who will listen!!
Posts.Title: Mets to abdominal cavity,kidney,urethra nurse-ann waterlily

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 02:10PM caligrlof68 wrote: My rad onc told me they like to start rads within 8 weeks of surgery for best results and least chance of 'regrowth'.  They cannot, however, start rads until your tissues are healed or else they will create more problems. I would put in a call to your rad onc. I had to do that because my wound wasn't healing and my surgeon had to debride it and open it back up again. So now I've had to delay my rads 2 to 4 weeks longer. I will be lucky if i get started by that magic 8 week window.  Stacy

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2009 08:26AM caligrlof68 wrote: scared- I haven't been through exactly what you're going through, although I can offer my opinion based on my experiences with breast cancer thus far. The chemo is bad, but it isn't all that bad. You'll lose your hair. You'll be fatigued beyond belief. You may even have other weird SE's. But it is definitely something you can do!! The bilateral mastectomy....well, that would be the ideal choice,however, it doesn't drop your risk of recurrence to 0%. I am having a single mastectomy on weds feb 25. I need a double mast., however, my life is so messed up and complicated right now that I am opting to do 2 separate surgeries so that my recovery is easier. The beauty of this website is there are MANY MANY women here who have gone through just what you're describing. Read through some other posts and you will find those people. You can even send them a private message....I'll bet they respond to you quickly....and have some help/advice/support for you. Best of luck! Stacy

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 01:14PM caligrlof68 wrote: Wow Terri, It sounds as though you've been through a tough time lately. The trouble with ILC is that it doesn't grow as a mass, but rather as thread like projections..single file cells in a line. For this reason, and at the recommendation of my surgical oncologist, I had a mastectomy rather than a lumpectomy. I had an MRI to 'size' my cancer prior to surgery. My original core biopsy showed two tumors less than 1 cm each....the MRI showed a 7 cm tumor!! It also showed smaller areas...that after chemo were unchanged. Turned out they were LCIS...but it wasn't until I had the mastectomy that they discovered the LCIS. To clarify.. I had neoadjuvant chemo. Now, I am comfortable with my decision to have the mastectomy...even though the chemo made my tumor in my breast completely disappear, and I knew this before hand because I had an MRI after finishing my chemo.  Regarding ultrasound.. I had one initially and the tech found an area that the radiologist confirmed was questionable. The US guided biopsy was scheduled, I returned for my appt, the tech could NOT find the questionable area, I was asked to return so the original tech and original radiologist could find the area to biopsy, I did, it was located and biopsied, it was cancer...nuff said. Clearly US depends on the knowledge and expertise of the tech!!  Another issue.. ILC doesn't generally show up on mammogram....go figure! It's the sneaky breast cancer!! Stacy

We have another date set for Saturday afternoon....gotta sneak around so my DS has NO idea I'm dating as he just wants me to find him a new Dad. No pressure or anything!! Well, he thinks I'm way sexy....haha! Truth be told...he's definitely got my hormones in high gear. 2new1's...Wow! No stress or anything, huh? I just don't know what to say. I haven't had that issue with my 17 yr old DS. I was just a tad like that...and nothing my parents did worked. Not sure if a contract would work...you know, get him to talk about his behavior...his school work...and have his teachers all on board with daily reports from them...his freedom depends on how well he manages to follow the behavior contract. Perhaps a visit to planned parenthood, or a discussion about teen pregnancy might get him thinking. Are these young girls on birth control?? Are they using condoms?? So much he needs to learn. Is he ready to be a father? Could he support a baby for the next 18 years?? All questions he should be thinking about. You could always do what I did to my husband...take him to the doctor for STD testing. The swab up the urethra was quite the incentive to NOT have unprotected sex. Quite painful I hear.  With regards to the girls mothers...remind them that it takes 2. He isn't forcing himself on these girls. They are more than willing. Maybe  you could meet with the girls' moms??

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 05:35AM caligrlof68 wrote: samiam...the scar massage simply put is simply moving and stretching the skin on what used to be the breast....it releases adhesions that have formed and keeps the skin loose and supple. It is slow gentle 'slipping and sliding' of the skin across the muscle/fascia below. I hope that makes sense to you. It's definitely easier to 'get' when you're shown the process.. but it isn't super technical. So I see my surgeon again this morning(he is very handsome and nice...so this is a GOOD thing!). I still have one drain in (since 2-25). It is consistently putting out 80 cc's of yellow fluid, so I'm not sure I want it out. How long can these things stay in safely? I wish I knew. I have no sign of infection yet. What if the darn thing never stops draining? Then what do i do? Any one have answers for me? Stacy

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 07:55PM caligrlof68 wrote: When I go back under the knife....once my life has stabilized somewhat...I will have the lat flat with implants. Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 07:07AM caligrlof68 wrote: Deen, I agree that my JP seems to be putting out so much. I think it has to do with my receiving OT...she does the MLD(manual lymphatic drainage) on my affected side. I do plan on toughing it out over the weekend....otherwise i fear i'd end up in the ER with a huge seroma. 2new1s, Being in the hospital is so hard... I hope you start to feel better soon. It has to be so disappointing to go through this after all you have already been through. grrr.  Don't you just wish the sun would shine on you just one day? That's how I feel sometime...just one day of sunshine please!!  Speaking of the uncomfortable hospital bed... you could try complaining about it. I work in a hospital and know that most have several versions of bed available. Some are much more comfortable than others. If your tailbone area is feeling bruised from sitting in that hard bed, make sure you are getting up to the chair several times a day. Also, make sure you are getting enough protein. They should have a medical dietician available to see  you. She can get you some tasty supplements that are rich in healing protein. All you need to do is ask...ask....ask! Stacy

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 11:57AM caligrlof68 wrote: jillisucat....I just don't understand some men. 6 weeks and he won't even look at your new chest? Does he think it is supportive to just ignore all this cancer junk? Some men need a swift kick in the hiney. On the other hand...20 years of marriage and he hasn't left you or cheated on you...something to be said for that too!   2new1's...The brotherhood of cheating losers....I think a lot of men could belong!! Ever since I knew my husband I always had the feeling that he was going to shoot me in the back. Now, I pushed it out of my head, but couldn't completely ignore it since he's a hunter and owns a dozen guns. I thought I was crazy for thinking that! At this time I think maybe it was my 'gut' telling me that this guy was NO GOOD!  I believe there is someone out there for me...now I just need to get out of bed or off the sofa and go OUT!! Stacy

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 07:36AM caligrlof68 wrote: Samiam40, YES.. the skin on my chest feels odd to me. You described it well... sandpapery, numb, yet hypersensitive.  It isn't really painful, yet when i touch it it's very sensitive, so i tend to avoid rubbing that area too much. I am starting to gently massage lotion in that area while i do that skin/scar massage like my PT/OT taught me to do. It's slow going, but if this is my new normal then I must learn to deal with it. And yes, good riddance is my thought too. I am still mourning the loss of the relationship, but every day it gets easier for me. To the future! Stacy
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 09:46AM caligrlof68 wrote: I thought it would really be a sad day when i checked out my boobless left chest for the first time...but it's a non issue. I know I'm quite irreverent about most sh#t in my life. I have to laugh when the skin sparing part of my mastectomy jiggles like a tiny A cup next to my naturally jiggly D cup. I suppose I'll be ready for my new foobs if for nothing else something to wash in the shower. What I mean is...you know when you get your hair cut real short and go to wash it and there's nothing there and your hands just run out of hair to wash? That's how my chest is... on the left side... I go to wash my chest area and my right hand has a boob to wash... my left hand is sorta lost there for a moment.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 05:12PM caligrlof68 wrote: Yes, Sam... 400 cc's...OMG do i feel better. It was starting to look like i was growing a square boob! Felt very full. After my shower, I bent over to dry off my feet and felt dripping.. so.. YES.. it was draining.. onto my foot and the carpet. OOPS!!  I really think you should live on the edge and go for 50 cc's!! Just remember to take your  pain meds before u go. Dani.. Zumba sounds fun fun fun! Do they bring in good looking latin men to dance-exercise with? Now THAT would be great!! and so motivating!! I have that same front hook sports bra from walmart.. $7 dollars! I love it! Of course, I don't have expander bricks on my chest YET!!

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 03:41PM caligrlof68 wrote: Cathie,  I completely understand where you're coming from. I am only 40 and I feel like I have been through the ringer since my diagnosis in August. I am starting my Rads in a few weeks and I, too, and afraid of the fatigue that I just know will make me feel cruddy all over again. One thing that I have done, which might help you, is to start taking anti depressants. I feel 100 times better since I started taking them. I realize that pills aren't for everyone...but this one sure helps to smooth out the rough spots in this rocky road I never wanted to travel on. Stacy

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 07:28PM caligrlof68 wrote: swim. The benefit to having MRSA... you will always have a private room in the hospital from now on if you always make sure they know you tested pos for MRSA. Also, there are abx that treat MRSA....a fairly new one is called Linezolid or Zyvox. It's available in IV and pill form and both have been shown to be equally effective. I hope you were properly treated! Stacy

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 10:56AM caligrlof68 wrote: I am glad i saw this posting. I have been unable to work more than an occasional 8 hr shift here or there since the chemo always had my white count in the neutropenic range. Fortunately I have finished chemo and my immune system is fully functioning again!! I had my left mx on feb 25 and hope to go back to work next week...3 shifts, 8 hrs each. Normally we do the 12 hrs shifts on my floor, but since I have to do rads I won't be able to, gotta find time each day to get my daily dose of radiation.. grr.  The biggest problem is that on my floor the RNs do total patient care...we have no CNAs to help out. How is that going to work now that I am not supposed to lift, push, or pull with my left arm?

Posts.Title: What's your wierdest side effect ann-idiot ann-idiot

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 10:26AM caligrlof68 wrote: Hey ladies, I am just chiming in with my 2 cents as I finished my chemo at the end of January. I had AC x 4, weekly taxol x5, then taxotere x 2. I must say that I thought the taxotere was the worst. First of all it's 10 x's the cost of taxol...which seems odd to me. Secondly, it was the only med that i took that caused horrible mouth sores. Luckily you can get "magic mouthwash" from your doc that will numb your mouth enough to eat a meal of soft bland food. Ladyjane, make sure to tell your doc about the rashy redness...some people are allergic to the packaging of taxotere and would be better off using taxol. I had a friend who suffered that SE and her doc wouldn't use taxotere anymore. Just remember it will soon be over...you can do it!! You will be surprised how soon after finishing that you start feeling so much better. Stacy
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 10:52AM caligrlof68 wrote: I had neo AC x4 then 5 weekly doses of Taxol, afterwhich they had to switch me to taxotere because my hands went completely numb. So, finished up with 2 large doses of taxotere without too  many awful side effectes. At any rate, My MRI yesterday showed no evidence of cancer in my breast or nodes. Initiallly my tumor showed 7cm x 3 cm with one node enlarged.  I am just thrilled with this news and will be proceeding with a double mast at the end of this month. I am also starting my tamoxifen today!
Posts.Title: Anyone done neoadjavant chemo? mommy3abm Joyceska

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 10:09AM caligrlof68 wrote: Taxotere was rough Diana....you shouldn't have to fight with your insurance company over Neulasta shots to keep you out of the hospital...THAT should be a no-brainer!
Posts.Title: fingernail pain and fatigue pinkhd pinkhd

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 05:03PM caligrlof68 wrote: I have and it was no cake walk. I ended up not working through my chemo due to either fatigue, weak immune system, or pain. I felt that the AC regime was more do-able because they have meds to alleviate the side effects, mainly nausea. With the taxotere, the only thing they can give  you is a pain pill. That won't stop your nails from hurting, turning black, and falling off. I kept my nails cut very very short so they wouldn't get snagged on stuff. That helped a bunch. It'll be over with before you know it.. and you will feel better.. I promise!!   Stacy
Posts.Title: fingernail pain and fatigue pinkhd pinkhd
